modelCorrections.beforeModification: <div class="navbar-item header__item has-dropdown has-dropdown--vertical is-hoverable " aria-haspopup="true" aria-expanded="false" data-navlink-handle="about">
modelCorrections.afterModification: <div class="navbar-item header__item has-dropdown has-dropdown--vertical is-hoverable" aria-haspopup="true" data-navlink-handle="about">
modelCorrections.rawOutput:
Here's the corrected HTML based on the WCAG 2.1 violation description:

- Corrected HTML: <div class="navbar-item header__item has-dropdown has-dropdown--vertical is-hoverable" aria-haspopup="true" data-navlink-handle="about">

Explanation:
The `aria-expanded` attribute is not allowed on the `<div>` element according to the WCAG 2.1 guidelines. The `aria-expanded` attribute is typically used on elements that can expand or collapse, such as buttons or accordions, to indicate their current state. In this case, since the `<div>` element is not an expandable element, the `aria-expanded` attribute should be removed to ensure accessibility compliance.

modelCorrections.afterModification: <div class="navbar-item header__item has-dropdown has-dropdown--vertical is-hoverable" aria-haspopup="true" data-navlink-handle="media">
modelCorrections.rawOutput:
Here's the corrected HTML based on the WCAG 2.1 violation description:

- Corrected HTML: <div class="navbar-item header__item has-dropdown has-dropdown--vertical is-hoverable" aria-haspopup="true" data-navlink-handle="media">

Explanation:
The ARIA attribute `aria-expanded` is not allowed on the `<div>` element according to the WCAG 2.1 guidelines. Therefore, I removed the `aria-expanded="false"` attribute from the `<div>` element to make it compliant with the accessibility standards.
